CatDescriptText: Mrs. Betty Lou Wood, housewife, Hill District and Mr. Howard Urbanick, barber shop employee, Finleyville, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, July 14, 1962, pg. 17 with question: "Do you think it is ethical or right for a doctor to go on 'strike' as a protest?"  Mrs. Wood's answer reads: "No.  It seems that the Lord gave them the knowledge to help mankind.  They shouldn't let money get in front of them.  They are serving a much higher order."  Mr. Urbanick's answer reads: "I don't think so.  I've always thought doctors were supposed to be those who saved lives regardless."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Betty Lou Wood wearing light colored hat and eyeglasses, standing in front of C.A. Michel store with Pittsburgh Paints sign, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Howard Urbanick wearing paisley button down collared shirt, standing on Smithfield Street, Downtown
